demographics.name: Carlos Jones
demographics.supportServices: Social Work consult placed for assistance with transportation and housing stability. Referred to Lymphedema specialist for management of lower extremity edema. Nutritional support engaged due to painful oral lesions.
demographics.mobility: Ambulatory with difficulty due to significant bilateral lower extremity lymphedema and pain. Uses a cane for support. ECOG Performance Status 2.

diagnosis.pathologicStage: AIDS Clinical Trials Group (ACTG) Stage T1 I1 S0 (Tumor Stage: extensive oral/cutaneous; Immune Stage: CD4<200; Systemic Illness: No B symptoms/other opportunistic infections).
diagnosis.symptomsAtPresentation: Patient presents with dozens of violaceous skin plaques on his lower extremities, trunk, and face, with the left lower leg being most painful and ulcerated. He has painful lesions on his hard palate that interfere with eating. He also has severe, pitting lymphedema of both lower legs, causing pain and difficulty walking.
pathologyFindings: Skin Biopsy, Left Leg (04/01/2025): Dermal proliferation of spindle cells forming slit-like vascular spaces with extravasated red blood cells. Immunohistochemistry is positive for CD31, CD34, and strong nuclear positivity for LANA-1 (HHV-8), confirming the diagnosis of Kaposi Sarcoma.
diagnosis.relevantHistory: Patient was recently diagnosed with HIV after presenting to the emergency department. He was immediately started on Antiretroviral Therapy (ART). He has a history of IV drug use but is currently enrolled in a methadone program. No other significant medical history.
diagnosis.baselineStatus: ECOG 2. Patient is fatigued and in significant discomfort from oral lesions and leg edema/pain. Weight is down 10 lbs due to poor oral intake.

treatmentPlan.treatmentSite: Oral Palate & Left Lower Leg (LLE) Lesions
treatmentPlan.intent: Palliative (Control of painful oral lesions to improve nutrition, palliation of painful/ulcerated leg lesion, and overall disease stabilization).
treatmentPlan.modality: External Beam Radiation Therapy (EBRT) concurrent with Systemic Therapy and Antiretroviral Therapy (ART).
treatmentPlan.rtRxDetails: Oral Palate: 20 Gy in 5 fractions (4 Gy/fx). Left Lower Leg: 8 Gy in 1 fraction.
treatmentPlan.targetVolumeSummary: Palate: PTV encompasses the visible lesions on the hard palate with a 1 cm margin. LLE: PTV includes the cluster of painful/ulcerated lesions with a 1.5 cm margin.
treatmentPlan.techniqueSummary: Palate: 3D-CRT with opposed lateral photon fields to treat the hard palate while sparing the tongue. LLE: A single direct electron field with bolus to provide a uniform dose to the skin surface while sparing underlying tissue.
treatmentPlan.detailedConcurrentChemo: 20 mg/mÂ² IV every 3 weeks, managed by Dr. Reed. To be initiated concurrently with RT.
medications: Prophylaxis for opportunistic infections: Trimethoprim/Sulfamethoxazole (Bactrim) daily.
Lymphedema management: Compression stockings, leg elevation.
Magic Mouthwash PRN for oral pain.
therapistAlerts: Patient is immunosuppressed (HIV/AIDS) and on concurrent chemotherapy. High risk of infection. Practice universal precautions.
High risk for severe oral mucositis due to concurrent chemo/RT. Assess oral cavity daily. Report significant pain or sores.
Patient has significant lymphedema in the left leg. Handle leg gently during setup.
Two separate treatment sites with different techniques (photons and electrons). Verify correct patient, site, and plan for each treatment.
Monitor for signs of fatigue and dehydration. Encourage fluid intake.

ctSimulation.setupInstructions: Two separate setups: 1) Supine with a custom thermoplastic head mask and bite block to depress the tongue. 2) Supine with Vac-Lok bag for LLE, with bolus material placed over the clinical target.
ctSimulation.immobilization: Head mask with bite block (palate), Vac-Lok bag and sponges (LLE).
ctSimulation.referenceMarks: Mask marks for palate setup; clinical skin markings with tattoos for LLE electron field.
ctSimulation.ctNotes: CT simulation of two distinct sites performed. IV contrast used for the head/neck scan to delineate oral anatomy. Non-contrast scan for the LLE. Patient tolerated procedures well.

dosimetry.planStatus: Final - Approved by Dr. Samuel Chen (04/15/2025)
dosimetry.rx: Palate: 20 Gy/5 fx; LLE: 8 Gy/1 fx
dosimetry.constraints: Palate Plan: Tongue Max Dose < 15 Gy (achieved 14.5 Gy); LLE Plan: Dose falls off before reaching bone.
dosimetry.planNotes: Two separate palliative RT plans. The palate plan uses opposed lateral fields to treat the hard palate while sparing the majority of the tongue. The LLE plan uses a single electron field with bolus for a superficial target.

igrtProtocol.alignment: Palate: Match to bony anatomy of maxilla/mandible. LLE: Align to skin markings/tattoos.

fractions.immobilizationDevicesChecked: Head mask, bite block, LLE Vac-Lok
fractions.organTargetChecks: kV match for palate good. Clinical setup for LLE verified.
fractions.instructionsGiven: Reinforced oral hygiene instructions and use of Magic Mouthwash.
fractions.dailyNotes: Treated both palate (Fx 1/5) and LLE (Fx 1/1) today. Patient tolerated well. Coordinated with chemo suite for his infusion tomorrow.

fractions.patientConcerns: Mouth is starting to feel sore.
fractions.instructionsGiven: Encouraged proactive use of Magic Mouthwash before meals.
fractions.dailyNotes: OTV today. Patient has expected early mucositis. Leg lesion shows early signs of response (less weeping). Supportive care stressed.

fractions.siteSpecificSideEffects: Grade 2 oral mucositis. LLE skin shows resolving erythema.
fractions.patientConcerns: Mouth is very sore, but leg feels much better.
fractions.instructionsGiven: End-of-RT instructions provided. Continue intensive oral care and supportive meds. Mucositis should peak then heal over 1-2 weeks.
fractions.dailyNotes: Final fraction to palate delivered. Patient successfully completed both courses of palliative RT. Significant improvement in leg lesion, and oral lesions show early response despite mucositis.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Evelyn Reed (Oncology)
progressNotes.summary: Patient with newly diagnosed AIDS and advanced Kaposi Sarcoma (Stage T1I1S0). He is highly symptomatic from oral and cutaneous lesions. Given his symptom burden and immune status, I have recommended starting systemic therapy with Liposomal Doxorubicin. I have also referred him to Radiation Oncology for urgent palliative treatment to his most symptomatic sites (palate and LLE) to run concurrently with his first cycle of chemotherapy.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Samuel Chen (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Patient referred for urgent palliative RT for symptomatic KS. Exam reveals multiple painful lesions on the hard palate interfering with nutrition, and a large, painful, ulcerated plaque on his LLE. In conjunction with systemic therapy, we will proceed with palliative EBRT to both sites. Plan: 20 Gy in 5 fractions to the palate for durable local control, and a single 8 Gy fraction to the LLE for rapid palliation. Discussed expected side effects, including significant oral mucositis due to the concurrent chemotherapy. Patient understands and wishes to proceed.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Samuel Chen (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Patient has completed 3/5 fractions to his palate and his single fraction to the leg. He reports his leg pain is already significantly better. He is developing expected Grade 1 oral mucositis, which is managed with mouthwash. He is tolerating the concurrent chemo/RT well overall. Continue plan.
